Posts.Content: NiceCuppa I am a nurse (started in 1981) still working part time and I am sat here absolutely fuming that you have had to listen to this heartless thoughtless person. As part of our continued registration we have to revalidate every three years and require feedback from patients, students, fellow nurses. Please do this nurse a massive favour and write an account of what she said and how it made you feel. Date and sign it. The next time you visit the unit give this to either this nurse or the ward manager. Say it is feedback on her practice for her to use for her revalidation. Posts.Title: Just hours away from getting my biopsy results so scared

Posts.Content: Hi dminnimouse  Is the biopsy to give you a definite diagnosis? Do take someone with you either your husband or if he is sleeping after night shift take a good friend. Because they tell you things and you are so emotional you can't remember. I hope very much that these areas are benign or cysts and that is still a possibility. But if it is bad news you will find yourself on the treatment conveyor belt, you will be quickly and efficiently treated and breast cancer has excellent outcomes. Really the results and any treatment needed are completely out of your hands so there is no point in wearing yourself out with this emotion. Easier said than done I know. Now is the time to get on the phone to someone calm and reassurring and get them over for a chat after your husband has gone to work. I recently had to have a MRI of my spine and my lady vicar came round the evening before and was lovely and calmed me right down. The scan came back normal but I don't forget how scary it all is.  This time tomorrow you will know and will have a plan to sort it all out. It is scary but lots of ladies on here have been through it and come out the other side. I will be thinking about you xxxx

Posts.Title: Blood test for 'markers'

Posts.Content: Hiya London, Is it okay if I wear two hats to answer this question? The first hat is a sort of aging hippy hat....I take Ashwagandha powder sprinkle it on my cereal and in my coffee, its about £3.49p its a central nervous system relaxant...and obviously more relaxed = less pain. https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/ashwagandha Curcumin is an natural anti inflammatory and I also take this, its for the Letrozole aches and pains, I will put a link up for this  https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/turmeric Right the second hat is a nursing cap. As a previous writer has said for nerve pain they can prescribe Amitriptyline, this used to be prescribed for depression but now found to be useful for nerve pain, this also works on the central nervous system, Gabapentin is another one. At the moment you are on medication for mild-moderate pain the reason they are reluctant to put you on moderate-severe pain meds is of course the side effects. The next step up is codeine based stuff like Co-Codamol with all the constipation issues plus drowsiness. After that its morphine based stuff...Butrans patches 5mcg or 10mcg, they might be an option, maybe ask if you can try a Transdermal Analgesic Patch . Then there is Morphine sulphate tablets but there are strong side effects and you are looking after children so I don't think its appropriate. You absolutely deserve to be pain free, if it was me I would go with the natural stuff and also push the Doc for a low dose of Amitriptyline 5mg at bedtime and push to try a Butrans Transdermal Patch 5mcg. Hope this has been a bit helpful  xxx

Posts.Title: Results after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy, I would make an appointment with someone in HR or a senior manager who has knowledge of the 2010 Equality Act which protects you from discrimination. So unless other people in your former department are being moved into the new role, it appears to me that you ARE being discriminated against. I would get on the phone to macmillan and ask their advisers where you stand and then make an appointment with someone high up the food chain. I didn't have chemo, just lumpectomy and rads and I asked my manager if I could work a 12 hour night shift every Sat night, and she said whatever would help me. So I only took 3 weeks off and worked through the rads. I did it for the money, to keep in the loop at work and it made me feel 'normal'. Good luck and remember for the purposes of the law you are classed as disabled xxx

Posts.Content: hi amy66  I take Propolis https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/propolis  In mechanism of action it says.....  CAPE specifically inhibits nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-kB) (41). In human breast cancer cells, it also inhibits MDR gene expression, epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) (20). CAPE decreased malignancy potential of breast cancer stem cells via inhibition of self-renewal, progenitor formation, and clonal growth, and significantly decreased CD44 expression (42). CAPE-initiated S- and G2/M-phase cell-cycle arrests and apoptosis in human cervical cancer lines was associated with increased E2F-1 expression (43). I don't know if it 'helps'  but it certainly doesn't hurt xxx

Everyone at that clinic was waiting for results same as me, I know this because one of the health care assistants who organise the clinic was explaining to someone why they had to wait so long. I was in the consulting room, it had a bed in it but I was sat in a chair as nobody had told me to strip off or get on the bed. Anyway I could hear the staff laughing about something and I was glad because I thought they wouldn't be laughing if they are going to come in here and tell me bad news. My surgeon came in and said straight away...'clear margins and clear lymph nodes'  they were the best 6 words anyone has ever said to me. Posts.Title: Vitamin supplements & diet advice ?

Posts.Content: Hi Isingbass, I eat a mainly plant based diet, no meat no alcohol. I take Vitamins D3, K2, these two go together because the K2 helps the D3 to get to where it's supposed to go.  Vitamin B complex, Omega 3 fish oil, a mushroom extract compound, circumin, boswellia, green tea, flaxseed  (two desert spoons only ) Wheat Bran, Ashwaghda.  I have to say, I have no idea if any of this does the slightest good but it makes me feel a bit safer. When I get home I will tell you a couple of other things and put up a link to a reliable herbal website. I am out at the minute feeding the vicar's cats

Posts.Title: Letrozole and vertigo?

Posts.Content: Hi Theresa, I really hope the Exestamane works out for you and you can tolerate the side effects. If it doesn't work out there are other options. When I had side effects (from Letrozole) I looked into it and found out that very low doses of the drug wipes out your estrogen I will put a link up https://www.pharma.us.novartis.com/sites/www.pharma.us.novartis.com/files/Femara.pdf daily doses of 0.1 mg to 5 mg Femara (letrozole) suppress plasma concentrations of estradiol, estrone, and estrone sulfate by 75% to 95% from baseline with maximal suppression achieved within two-three days. Suppression is dose-related, with doses of 0.5 mg and higher giving many values of estrone and estrone sulfate that were below the limit of detection in the assays. Estrogen suppression was maintained throughout treatment in all patients treated at 0.5 mg or higher.  So this article which is by the makers of Femera the original drug says that 0.5mg completely suppresses estrogen. That is 1/5th of a tablet...so I cut the tablets up and take a small piece every day. Also another option is DIM and Indole-3-Carbinol. DIM short for Diindolylmethane cruciferous vegetables including broccoli, cabbage and cauliflower. It is the most studied of all I3C metabolites and is thought to be superior to IC3 as a chemoprotective compound for breast cancer. I will put a link up for the DIM as well https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/diindolylmethane  I hope you don't mind me flooding you with so much info but I didn't want you thinking you had run out of options Best Wishes

Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Hi Kacang I have access to the Open University library and I found quite a few articles I will try and post a link to one but it may not give you access  http://pmt-eu.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo_library/libweb/action/display.do;jsessionid=7D47CA022C65CA7284D33B8C54 . MATERIALS AND METHODS: This study included 60 postmenopausal osteopenic women. They were divided in two groups one group were administered 1gm calcium+ vitamin D3 1 mcg /day and other group were administered 1gm calcium+ vitamin D3 1mcg+vitamin K2 45mg/day. All the patients were investigated for bone marker undercarboxilated osteocalcin, N Telopeptide and bone mineral density. RESULTS: It was observed that group I that was treat with vitamin D3+calcium had less percentage improvement in bone mineral density and reduction of undercarboxilated osteocalcin and N telopeptide in comparison to patients who were treat with vitamin K2+vitaminD3+calcium observed had more percentage improvement in bone mineral density and reduction of undercarboxilated osteocalcin and N telopeptide. CONCLUSION-According the results of this study vitamin K2 to be more effective as a protective agent than combined calcium and vitamin D3 administration in cases of osteoporosis.

Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: Hi DnA  Sorry about your wife's diagnosis but to be honest the results you have posted don't look anything like advanced breast cancer to me. The ER8 means that the cancer cells will starved by taking am estrogen suppressant like Letrozole (that is the one I'm on) so the ER8 is good news. The HER2- means she wont have Heceptin. I'm no expert of course. I know it's rotten having to have treatment when you have had a healthy life but many ladies on here have had chemo, surgery and radiotherapy and it is an interruption to their life, not an end, nowhere near. Personally I got away with surgery, radiotherapy and then the Letrozole for 10 years. Anyway practical things you both could be doing....probably she will be starting treatment very quickly so stock the freezer/cupboards, buy some front fastening PJs, buy some cheap  comfy stretchy bras from Asda or similar that you can step into, alert any good, sensible mates who might come round and cheer her up. Prepare yourselves for maybe 6-12 months of disruption to your lives. Make her step away from the computer and go out for a lovely lunch then persuade her to join this group. We are a friendly bunch and she could chat to women going through the same. You're a good husband, and she's lucky to have you xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Mess90  I'm sure you must be very worried but you have made the first step to getting sorted out. At the breast clinic they will probably do a mammogram ultrasound and maybe a biopsy. Its a good idea to take a couple of paracetamol before you go because its a bit uncomfortable. Then I'm afraid its another wait for results :( waiting seems a feature...we are always waiting for something.  The result of the biopsy is what determines the diagnosis. You have faced up to going to the doctor and now facing up to the next couple of weeks is hard, but you have done another smart thing in coming onto this forum. Someone is here night and day, to give advice support or listen to any fears. Ladies on here have been where you are now and have come out the other side. Keep talking to us and hold on xxx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Bevdin, What happened to me was routine mammogram 20th July  recall letter 24th July ,  appointment for ultrasound and biopsy 30th July, diagnosis 5th Aug, lumpectomy and Sentinel node biopsy 18th Aug, result of SNB 27th Aug,  radiotherapy 6th oct-28th oct only mon-fri and then odd days off while they maintain the machines. I am not saying this is what will happen to you, as we are all different and all have different grades of cancer and treatment, but its just a rough guide what happened in the early days. I only know these dates because of pictures I took on my phone have the date on.
Posts.Title: biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor, I would keep your legs elevated and get some medical advice. Swollen ankles/legs mean your body is not getting rid of fluids as it should e.g. into your bladder and wee. Keep resting and ring the Doc x let us know how you are xxx
Posts.Title: Swollen legs/feet

Posts.Content: I'm afraid this is the problem...it makes your blood boil as well as your head explode. Do you watch the Supervet? the dogs or cats are brought in put under the MRI scanner or CT scanner while the owners are sat  in the waiting room. Forty minutes later the dogs family are brought in and are given the results.  Us humans have the scan, biopsy and wait for two, even three weeks for results. The problem is you're now in a system like a sausage in a sausage factory. Recently I had a MRI spine looking at a suspicious area on my spine, I eventually got a letter posted 2nd class on a Friday so I got the letter like Wednesday the next week, thank the Lord everything was alright but that was 5 days of stress waiting when someone could have rung me on the Friday. Blood boils, heads explode we feel your pain...that's the NHS BUT you will be seen and you will be sorted out xxx

Posts.Title: Side effects of medication

Posts.Content: Dearest Baki, Those who love you, would want the money spent on buying years and months with you.  I think the only thing that matters now is your comfort and peace of mind. If the tablets are keeping you feeling quite well and and able to get about and spend time doing things you like you must keep taking them. Use this time to do the things you have always wanted to do. I have just been to London on my own looking at all the museums.  Do things that that you want to do without any timescale or limit. Time to think again if your symptoms/side effects make life uncomfortable. Money is irrelevant when cancer rears its vile head. Thinking of you and hoping for your peace of mind and calmness.

Posts.Content: Session 4 today of radiotherapy, and I was sat quietly waiting to go in and I heard my name so I jumped up and ventured forward only to be shooed back. Then they shouted my name and this bloke said would I go on a different machine, so I said okay and trotted after him...and I said why were those people saying my name and he said they were discussing who would be able to go on a different machine. So I got on the table and they ran off and it started doing what it does and then a cough started in my chest and I had to lie there trying to control this cough, till I felt like my chest was going to explode. Eventually I coughed my head off and they came back, saying it was okay it was all finished when I stared coughing. They will think I am a total idiot. Best bit was my driver came as soon as I was out and zipped me home, no other passengers and I got home soon.

Posts.Title: Indole-3-carbinol and anti estrogen drugs.....any thoughts?

Posts.Content: Hiya, Your post caught my eye because I'm having a full spine MRI scan tomorrow :( completely dreading it. I had grade 1 stage 1 ER+8 August 2015 lumpectomy rads Letrozole.  Reason for MRI is I had bone scan in April for back pain. The scan showed loads of degenerative but also small suspicious area at Thoracic Vertebrae 7 which could also be degenerative but small focus of metatisic activity can't be entirely ruled out hence the MRI six months down the line.  In your case there are no reasons to look further. You're already on the best Al and the herceptin. If you think about it all of us who have had cancer will have had cells circulating in our bloodstream but all the doctors can do is give us drugs to starve the receptors and hope it doesn't grow in another organ.  I know it's really hard to stop worrying and enjoy life because that's what I'm trying to do myself at the moment and all I can think of is the suspicious area when today I could have had a lovely day with my fella. Try to believe the herceptin and the Al are starving and killing every cancer cell and I will try and believe the Letrozole is killing mine. Sending loads of hugs xxxc

Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy, So sorry you had such a rotten birthday. I'm answering because there is no need for you to be in pain in this day and age. You need stronger or different type of painkiller. Codeine is rubbish.  As it is Saturday go to Boots chemist and ask to speak to pharmacist privately  and explain the situation.  The strongest over the counter painkiller is called PARAMOL it is in a black box and is mix of paracetamol and Dyhdrocodine which is synthetic morphine. It's for short term use only, this is short term and for a valid reason. Obviously rebook GP and be insistent about better analgesic. Maybe the tumour is pressing on something causing this ache.  It's not right you're in pain with all the cancer stuff to face. Sending hugs let us know how you go on xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Janet14, You're not going crazy, the physical symptoms you are experiencing are probably anxiety, people assimilate fear in different ways. This feeling won't  last ,it is something you are going through, not something you are going to stay in forever. I was diagnosed in Aug 2015 and I stick around on this site to 'haul the newbies into the lifeboats' as Carolyn28 says. There are many stages and grades of breast cancer with different receptors which can all be treated. For example my tumour was 12mm and was grade 1 stage 1 and ER positive and I just had a lumpectomy (scar almost invisible now) 15 radiotherapy (doesn't hurt at all) and tablets for 10 years (that's another story, pain in the arse). So although it is utter poo to have the thing at all it may not be as bad as you are thinking. They don't know a thing until they have those cells under a microscope. Hold on these day's will pass and keep on posting, that is what we are here for, to haul you into the lifeboat, honestly you're not going to sink xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Marlog, What has happened to you today is because you have gone against their system ( you probably have realised this) The path lab will have looked at the tissue almost straight away. What happens is that they have a meeting and decide on your treatment and then when they give you the results there is a plan of treatment to give you. I myself was very cross that loads of people knew I had cancer before I did. But the reason is that a group of experts come together to give their input, years ago it would be one (often male surgeon) who would make the decision what would happen to your breast.  So is it annoying that these people know about your cancer before you......Yes very But much better to have a group of people all giving their best input and when you are told the news...then they can say...'and this is what we are going to do about it'. I am sorry you are upset...probably the breast nurse who lied to you is upset also and will be carpeted

I was totally spoilt with people turning up with fish n chips, omelette ingredients, bread, fruit etc. I completely milked the situation it was lovely. Please tell your family and friends x

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, I have had a lovely Easter in spite of working, and hope you have too. Oh Lou...these horrid tablets I am supposed to be on Letrozole, which made me dizzy then I started getting heart bangs and booms. I'm too scared to stop em all together so taking minuscule amounts and waiting for appointment with cardiologist. So to answer your question yes go and see the doctor about it all. Another thing you could do if really worried is ring the macmillan number and speak to one of the nurses, they know all about this stuff. Good luck x
Posts.Title: help what are these throbbing pains ?

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine, It depends what stage in your treatment you are.  If you are having surgery or chemo I would think take nothing unless prescribed by your doctor. However if you are passed all that I cannot see any objections to a multivitamin, I take loads of supplements. Vitamin D3 and K2 and a vitamin B complex, vitamin E drops for starters. The other things are herbs or food extracts which are supposed to be cancer helpers. Oh and I take 2 spoonfuls of flaxseed and 2 cups of Rooibos tea this was okayed by the chief medical officer of the UK when there was an open forum. Best Wishes

Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: Hello French, Your situation sounds like mine August 2015. I had a 12mm grade 1, stage 1, tumor taken out by lumpectomy, I had nothing in my lymph nodes, so I had 15 sessions of radiotherapy then Letrozole a hormone inhibitor tablet. I managed to work at weekends all the way through the radiotherapy, it was tiring but doable. Because I had a lumpectomy and no chemo my life has had much less disruption than many of the ladies on here who have more surgery and chemo. So I would say yes, this is a much bigger thing than flu the treatment brings changes to your body, the radiotherapy and the hormone tablets have side effects we could do without. Also there are psychological implications, you have had cancer and you will always think differently now. But I think you and I French, have hopefully dodged some of the bullets and life will soon get back to a new 'normal'.  My best wishes for the rest of your treatment, keep in touch let us know how you go on x

Posts.Title: Confusion over R1 and R2

Posts.Content: Morning everyone, I'm writing to you ladies because I am really worried. I have had this pain in my pelvis it started about 6 months before the breast cancer was diagnosed, I foolishly swung a heavy trolley up a ramp and I thought the pain stared then. So its been there off and on ever since, never told anyone about it. This last weekend it got go much worse I could hardly walk, pins and needles in my toes. Went to the doctor Monday, had x-rays and bloods to be taken Thursday. So I don't know if I should continue taking the Letrozole, is it that causing the pain in the sacrolliac joint? Or is it bone mets and I've had it all along?  I'm coming to you asking these questions because I'm going to see my daughter and see her wedding dress thats just arrived and its supposed to be a happy day, and if I pour it all out to you it gets it off my chest. The pain is horrible stopping me sleep.

I hope it goes well for us and the other lady on this thread. Keep in touch xxx

Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi adassrose,  When you get in bed place one hand over your heart and one hand on your tummy. Breathe in thinking a positive thought or image for example...a grandchild's face or a walk on the beach. Breathe out through the hand on your tummy. Breathe in through the hand on your heart a positive thought like 'I've been diagnosed and the Nhs will sort it' Breathe out through the hand on yr tummy. Breathe in through the hand on yr heart a nice activity for tomorrow....e.g. coffees with friends. Or a simple one I do is 'I am safe, I am loved, everything will be okay' Every time a negative thought creeps in replace it with a positive. It's called heart breathing xx

Posts.Title: Lowering Letrozole dose?

Posts.Content: Hi Whiskat  I had three weeks of radiotherapy after a lumpectomy and to be honest it was no big deal. The boob gets a bit hot and pink and you're knackered at the end, I worked a 12 hour shift every Sat night, but it was worth it to lower the risk of local recurrence. I hope you don't mind but I put your stats in the Predict tool and you gain 0.5% chance of survival at 5 years and 1.5% at ten years by taking the tabs. I know it's not much. But to your doctor who might be seeing 200 ladies a year that means 3 more ladies survive through taking the tabs. Of course it is your body and you must do what you think best i was just putting my view forward. Best of luck what ever you decide xxxx

Posts.Title: Quality of life 7 weeks in??

Posts.Content: Hi Misty,  It all sounds absolutely horrific and my heart goes out to you. You have indeed been abandoned.  By opting for palliative care rather than active treatment you deserve more than a prescription for morphine.  I'm just trying to wrack my brain how you could receive support if the hospice is not responding. The district nurses you mention are probably responsible for physical care like dressings but they are very pushed for time.  Please contact the district nurses and ask who is responsible for your end of life care plan....because you will have a named nurse and then tell them your needs, which at the moment seems to be befriending rather than nursing care. Meanwhile please join the wonderful AWAKE thread on here. Lovely ladies who chat about anything and everything and would be happy to give online support. You are not alone any more xxx

Posts.Title: vitamin D - who knows their vitamin D levels are low ?

Posts.Content: Hi Leonaw123  You shouldn't say sorry for posting, that it what we are here for, someone is always here for you. At least you got the letter and know that the biopsy is going to give you the answers you need. When I had my ultra sound the lump looked like a little pebble on the screen it was 12mm. Because of my age (I was 52) the probability was that it was cancer and it was, but stage 1 which has very good outcomes. When you do get the appointment for your results there will have already been a Multi disciplinary team meeting, that is a group of experts will have had a meeting and discussed your results and decided on a treatment plan. This is one of the reasons for the delay in you getting the results, very annoying but it is really a good thing, because in the old days you would get one consultant, usually male deciding everything. But this is all running ahead because your results may be  benign. Meanwhile, when you have had all the scans its just a matter of waiting for the Lab report

Posts.Title: Christmas Wishes

Posts.Content: Hi Loolou, from reading your post I gather that by having chemo you increase your chances of survival by 2%. It is very difficult for any of us to say don't have the chemo because we would always be worried we had influenced you and then you could (God forbid) be in the 2% of women who would have benefited from it. However you are more than a statistic and your life is about much more than breast cancer, so what I am saying is only you know what is most important to you. Maybe you have hobbies and interests that you really love and the chemo would stop you doing them. Whatever you decide I would back you all the way. love from
Posts.Title: help needed re chemo or not

Posts.Content: Hi Franm, What struck me reading your list of medication is that all those medicines are to protect and help you. I am on Letrozole myself and know the nasty side effects...but it is there to protect you and me from the cancer coming back. The Statin which has recently been in the news (the other day) has been cleared of many of the accusations against it and it protects thousands maybe millions  from heart disease and strokes. The diabetic medication.... I take it you are tablet and diet controlled...is there to prevent damage to your body from the diabetes.  Most people don't like being on meds, but looking at your trio I would say they are a friendly helpful bunch. I hope this answer gives you an alternative view. I'm sorry you are having problems, stress through serious illness like breast cancer is enough to give us anxiety and memory problems. Best wishes from
